intro: Uva-ursi andersonii, commonly known as Anderson's bearberry, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes many shrubs and small trees adapted to acidic soils. The plant produces small, white or pink flowers in the spring, followed by red berries that are edible for birds and small mammals. Its leaves are thick, waxy, and contain compounds that have been historically used in traditional medicine. Uva-ursi andersonii thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and rocky stream banks.
